description_html.en-US:
The Math Diagnostic is available from 8am-8pm EDT. It will take 90 minutes once you start. On August 6, the exam will appear on this website: https://lms.mitx.mit.edu/courses/course-v1:MITx+MDX_2020+2020_Fall/course/

Please use the Chrome browser for the exam!

If any issues arise with Proctortrack, please contact them: https://lms.mitx.mit.edu/courses/course-v1:MITx+ASE+onboarding/courseware/c6fd049be699479b930c13c8ef1917f7/75f095ed836f4380aff6fd7d3d11fc3a/?activate_block_id=block-v1%3AMITx%2BASE%2Bonboarding%2Btype%40sequential%2Bblock%4075f095ed836f4380aff6fd7d3d11fc3a

August 18th

DMSE FPOP Day 1 (Open Day) 12-6PM

https://mit.zoom.us/my/nignacio


Intro to DMSE (12-2)

What is materials science and engineering? How is it different from Course 2? 5? 8? 10? 20? Why is glass clear and metal shiny? Can we make plastic that won’t become a pollutant? Come hear the DMSE FPOP coordinators give their completely unbiased opinion on what makes Course 3 the best major. (Feat. our Department Head Jeffrey Grossman at 1PM)

3.091 Presentation (2-3)

Come by to hear Professor Don Sadoway discuss his research on the future of battery storage and transforming the energy grid. Stay to learn about 3.091, Introduction to Solid State Chemistry, a General Institute Requirement (GIR) taught by Prof. Sadoway this fall described by Bill Gates as the “best chemistry lessons anywhere.”

Meet the DMSE Professors (3-4)

Attend a panel discussion with Course 3 Professors. Come ask questions about their research, classes and anything else!

DMSE Subject Presentations (4-6, 20 min sessions)

Explore the ubiquity of materials science through presentations given by DMSE students! See presentations on anything from biological and tissue engineering to phase field modeling to food science!

Date: August 21, 2020

Zoom link will be uploaded soon.


Description

Most of our program highlights will include talks from BCS professors about their cutting-edge work in Brain and Cognitive Sciences. The videos that we have shared for our program cover everything from an introduction to the study of brain and cognitive sciences to how cognitive neuroscience can help children and young people. We will also feature exciting behind the scenes virtual lab tours of multiple labs within our department including but not limited to the Harnett Lab, Saxe Lab, Federenko Lab and more.

Zoom link: http://web.mit.edu/webcast/ome/f20/1/


This year, due to COVID-19, the Office of Minority Education will offer its annual OME Parent/Student Orientation virtually. This exciting information session is designed to give parents, and incoming students, a broad introduction to the many programs and services offered by the OME team. OME team members will also discuss how they will support students throughout the fall term in a virtual environment. At the end of the session, the OME team will respond to questions and offer their insights on the overall MIT student experience. The OME is all about community. In fact, it is affectionately called hOME by many current MIT students. Community will be even more important this fall. Please join us and learn more about what we have planned. We look forward to connecting with all of you!

All students from non-denominational or other denominational backgrounds are welcome to attend. For students and parents. (Sponsored by Rev. Michael Dean, Baptist Chaplain, mdean@mit.edu)

objects.name: Being Christian at MIT? - Navigating New Waters

description_html.en-US:
Zoom link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/92585398266


What’s it like for students to maintain or find faith in college? What is the Christian community like at MIT? What are Churches like in the area? What things can students get involved in? Come meet some staff with Cru as well as some of the Cru students. Ask questions. Meet other parents. Drop in anytime. Feel free to bring your son or daughter as well. Cru is a non-denominational Christian ministry at MIT. If you can’t make it, please stop by www.mitcru.com to learn more and fill out a connect form.

objects.name: All About GIR 3.091: Talks with Two Docs from an Electronic Box

description_html.en-US:
Zoom link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/99394801652


Join Profs. Don Sadoway and Raf Jaramillo to find out more about 3.091: Introduction to Solid-State Chemistry, one of the three MIT General Institute Requirements (GIRs) for chemistry. Why 3.091? Why take a chemistry GIR now? What sorts of things will I learn? How will this help me with future classes at MIT? Is it a good prerequisite? How is it the same or different from other chemistry GIRs? How useful is solid-state chemistry out in the world (and could I find a job using it)? For this event, Profs. Sadoway and Jaramillo created a short video to answer our three most common questions, followed by live Q&A to answer any other ones you may have.
This time is held meetings/registration appointments with your first year advisor. Your advisor will email you to confirm your meeting/registration appointment date, time, and Zoom location.

Renewable energy has long ceased to be a fad; it’s the essential lifeblood for a sustainable planet. Learn about projects and other hands-on activities in Renewable Energy Machines, a NEET academic community working to build energy production, conversion, storage, and transmission technologies that produce little to no CO2 or greenhouse emissions.

Staff members will talk about wellness activities, physical education, intramurals, club sports, open recreation, and intercollegiate athletic teams. We’ll help you find an activity best suited for your interests and schedule. This is the first of a 5 part series. Join us in the other sessions for a deeper dive into each program area. The other 4 sessions include varsity athletics, club sports and intramurals, physical education and wellness, and recreation.

objects.name: Edgerton Center and D-Lab Open House

description_html.en-US:
Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/91206385050

What is the Edgerton Center? How does a student-built solar car, a machine shop, and a course in high-speed imaging fit together? It’s all learning by doing. Find out about some of our courses such as EC.120, Electronics Project Lab, EC.305, Digital and Darkroom Imaging, and more (link to our courses page). Consider joining one of our student teams like the Solar Electric Vehicle Team or the Rocket Team.

What is D-Lab? Take an MIT D-Lab class and become an effective agent of global change while at MIT and beyond! Through our courses, students will participate in the design process, apply principles of engineering and design, engage in hands-on shop work, and learn to think critically about theories of development.

Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/98593850906


Welcome to MIT Orientation! Hillel provides Jewish life on campus, and now virtually! Meet the Jewish community, get to know your Jewish peers, and participate in an AMA with members of the Hillel Student Board and Staff.

Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/95182929966


Gather around the scanning electron microscope and explore the microscopic world with the MIT Museum. Meet your classmates and learn about the exhibits, programming, and opportunities that the MIT Museum has to offer in this virtual meetup. Is there something you would like to explore in the microscope? If so, please send suggestions to bmernoff@mit.edu

Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/91094814661 ; use "arts" as password


Join us to learn about what the arts have to offer at MIT! From visual art and design to music and theater arts, and interdisciplinary work, for credit or extra academic--whether you're looking to try something new or major/minor/concentrate in the arts--we have you covered. Learn about funding for art projects, or access to the arts both on and off campus. Find out what groups you can join and ways to meet others who love the arts, no matter what field of study you may want to pursue. ALL are welcome to join! We're here to provide info and answer any questions you may have about how you can get involved and join our arts community at MIT! arts.mit.edu

This live, 20-minute class is a combination of simple stretches to release tension in the body and guided meditation to mentally reset during the day. It will be offered Monday through Thursday during Orientation Week to encourage creating a self-care routine.
UROP staff provide an overview on all things UROP and answer your questions. Experienced UROP students/supervisors may join to offer their firsthand experiences, schedules permitting.

With the continued growth of the Institute’s public art collection, MIT’s campus has become a destination for art lovers. In order to support the growing interest in the collection from the community at large, the List Center recently launched a new MIT student led tour program. Join MIT List Visual Arts Center on a unique tour of campus highlighting MITs public art. Learn more about the public art collection and student involvement with the List Center on this co-led student guide and List Center staff virtual tour of the List Center’s collection of renowned contemporary artists – including, Alexander Calder, Olafur Eliasson, Sol LeWitt and more.

Your Terrascope Advisor will talk about logistics around registering for classes, contact information, general expectations for the advising relationship, and events that will be taking place this year. This session is mandatory for students being advised by Terrascope.

Full List of SCUFFY events available here.


Excited to be starting your first year at MIT, or worried about Zoom classes? Either way, all the upperclassmen are here for you! We’re virtualizing the classic MIT first-year experience, so that you can find and join a dorm community that works for you. Find out more at scuffy.mit.edu!

We’re having an extravaganza of 173 events from August 23-30 to showcase all our wild and wacky dorms and cultural houses. On August 27 and 28, you’ll be able to rank the dorms, and get placed in a community by August 30! Note: participation in SCUFFY is optional, but encouraged. The SCUFFY Dorm Placement is not tied to Housing and Residential Services, and will have no bearing on your housing assignments in future semesters.

You can also try to join one of MIT’s 5 Cultural Houses, each with its own cultural connections and set of commitments. Find out more at this page, and if you’re interested make sure you join an info session!

Questions? Email ask-scuffy@mit.edu.

Head over to the #slack-chat-dormcon channel in the Orientation 2020 workspace to talk with students about dorm life at MIT, as well an initiative to welcome 2024s into dorm life (called SCUFFY). Can't make this time? No worries! The transcript will live on.

You will get to ‘hang out’ with the OME team in an informal context, meet some of your peers, and you will also be eligible to win some great raffle prizes. Join us for a night of fun and games!

Come join ABSK for a worship service with Chaplain Dave to begin this Orientation Week. You'll also get to hear 10 tips to survive MIT from upperclassmen and alums. You don't want to miss this one. ABSK stands for Asian Baptist Student Koinonia. You don't have to be Asian, you don't have to be Baptist, and you don't have to know what koinonia means. You do have to be a student though. For more info please visit http://www.facebook.com/mitabsk.

objects.name: How Will You Impact the World? Meet the Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) for a Casual Info Session!

description_html.en-US:
Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/97193170257


You came to MIT to solve the world’s most challenging and complex problems. MIT will give you the academic foundation to do that, but those problems will not be solved alone; they will be solved in teams – and those teams will be led by the next generation of engineering leaders. The Gordon-MIT Engineering Leadership Program (GEL) will help you develop the capabilities you will need to leverage your technical skills for maximum impact. GEL also offers its students unique professional development opportunities, and connections with our extensive industry network and an active and growing alumni network. Meet GEL staff members and students for an informal info session and Q&A For more info: gelp.mit.edu/admissions

Zoom link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/97565543854

description_html.en-US:
Register here to access Zoom Link: http://bit.ly/lcecafe25


Meet other language learners and exchange languages with the MIT Language Conversation Exchange (LCE). Join LCE Cafe to meet other language enthusiasts, students taking learning languages, and native speakers of languages you’d like to practice. The LCE cafes start with a short language or cultural presentations. Then we send participants into small breakout rooms to practice languages they are learning or want to improve. Registering ahead of time makes the assignment of participants to breakout language rooms easier and faster. You will receive an email with your personalized zoom link after the registration.


Can't make our Zoom events? Search for conversation partners in the MIT community on our website: http://lce.mit.edu . Partners meet at their convenience.

description_html.en-US:

The Department of Earth, Atmospheric and Planetary Sciences (EAPS) at MIT is where the turbulent oceans and atmosphere, the inaccessible depths of the inner Earth, distant planets, and the origins of life all come together under one intellectual roof.
This event will feature a talk by EAPS faculty member, Professor David McGee, followed by a student panel where incoming freshmen can learn about what it’s like to be an EAPS undergraduate from upperclassmen in the major.

Head over to #slack-chat-support channel in the Orientation 2020 workspace to talk with students and staff about how to access support and ways to stay well during your first year at MIT. Can’t make this time? No worries! The transcript will live on.

Excited to be starting your first year at MIT, or worried about Zoom classes? Either way, all the upperclassmen are here for you! We’re virtualizing the classic MIT first-year experience, so that you can find and join a dorm community that works for you. Find out more at scuffy.mit.edu!


We’re having an extravaganza of 173 events from August 23-30 to showcase all our wild and wacky dorms and cultural houses. On August 27 and 28, you’ll be able to rank the dorms, and get placed in a community by August 30! Note: participation in SCUFFY is optional, but encouraged. The SCUFFY Dorm Placement is not tied to Housing and Residential Services, and will have no bearing on your housing assignments in future semesters.

objects.name: Finding God at MIT - Worship Night and Student Stories

description_html.en-US:
Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/98431312183


Do students at MIT believe in God? Yes! Lots of us do! Come check out Cru, a diverse group of students who are seeking to follow Jesus at MIT. Grab your favorite beverage, find a comfortable place to sit and come enjoy a time of worship with the Cru band and hear inspiring stories from students who have found out how to thrive in their faith at college. We’ll have time in breakout rooms to meet other first years and upperclassmen in Cru. Great giveaways too! Cru is a non-denominational Christian student group on campus. If you can’t make it, please stop by www.mitcru.com to learn more and fill out a connect form.

Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/99449253443

This time is held meetings/registration appointments with your first year advisor. Your advisor will email you to confirm your meeting/registration appointment date, time, and Zoom location.

Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/93777836813


A panel of first-generation and/or low income students and alumni will share their MIT experiences, insights, and answer your questions about. Learn about opportunities within the MIT FGLI community and connect with other incoming students.

objects.name: All About GIR 3.091: Talks with Two Docs from an Electronic Box

description_html.en-US:
Zoom link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/99394801652


Join Profs. Don Sadoway and Raf Jaramillo to find out more about 3.091: Introduction to Solid-State Chemistry, one of the three MIT General Institute Requirements (GIRs) for chemistry. Why 3.091? Why take a chemistry GIR now? What sorts of things will I learn? How will this help me with future classes at MIT? Is it a good prerequisite? How is it the same or different from other chemistry GIRs? How useful is solid-state chemistry out in the world (and could I find a job using it)? For this event, Profs. Sadoway and Jaramillo created a short video to answer our three most common questions, followed by live Q&A to answer any other ones you may have.
These events make up the main part of orientation - don't miss them!

How do OLs handle the tough stuff at MIT? How did they make the most a partially virtual Spring semester? OLs will discuss the support resources that are available at MIT for students to help them stay well. Note: This is not a full day event. Your OL will determine the exact time and send you Zoom information to meet.

objects.name: Ancient and Medieval Studies at MIT -- including Latin, Greek, and Old English!

description_html.en-US:
Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/94289595556

Did you know that you can study Latin and Greek here at MIT -- as well as Old English, the Norse sagas, the dynasty of Charlemagne, the cities of ancient Athens and Rome, the archaeology of ancient Syria, the economy of pre-modern Europe, and so much more! The Ancient and Medieval Studies Program (AMS) is a thriving community of students and scholars who share an interest in the pre-modern world, with faculty coming from disciplines across the Institute, including Literature, History, Music, Philosophy, Architecture, Archaeology, and Material Sciences. Come learn more about our concentration, minor, and major -- or just meet with like-minded faculty and classmates who are interested in thinking about the importance of past at one of the most future-orientated institutions on earth!

Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/94021162563


Join the Global Languages Academic Administrator for an information session to learn about the many options for studying languages at MIT. We will discuss the various programs we offer for concentrations, minors, and majors, and how you can apply coursework in 21G to satisfy the General Institute Requirements. Information about the current course offerings for AY2020-2021 will be provided as well as how to have your language level assessed by instructors in Global Languages.

Zoom Link: http://mit.zoom.us/j/3474141374


Come meet Chabad at MIT, 'home away from home' for Jewish students at MIT! Rabbi Menachem and Mussy would love to e-meet you and answer any questions you may have about Jewish life at MIT!

objects.name: NEET: Creating the future of manufacturing: 3D printing

description_html.en-US:
Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/92002939462

3D printing technologies are no longer only being used in R&D and prototyping, but are seeing increasing use in mainstream manufacturing. This shift is changing how we think about design and manufacturing in the 21st center. Join our session to learn how scholars in the AMM thread explore the subject of 3d printing through hands-on projects, such as building and operating their own 3d printers, and also through advanced research into cutting edge materials and processes that are helping bring the flexibility of 3d printing together with the volume and cost needed in manufacturing.

MIT’s Solar Electric Vehicle Team (SEVT) is faced with a unique challenge: design, manufacture, and construct a solar-powered vehicle from scratch to compete in a long distance endurance race. By long distance, we mean about 2,000 miles. Students from across disciplines come together to create a community of teammates and friends working to solve real-world problems with significant impacts. Apart from engineering, members learn invaluable business and project-management skills by approaching this challenge from a higher level. As a student-run team, this project is our heart and soul, and we are able to learn and grow as engineers, teammates, and people as we face new challenges in the world of solar.
Live Q &A with members of the Club Chem team.

As we navigate the continued COVID-19 pandemic and the impact of identity on community impact, we also strive for racial justice amid an election year that will be like no other. Join Danny from the PKG for a discussion about what change you (yes, you!) can make on the world and social issues like these. We will be reviewing what opportunities exist at MIT while opening a space for you all to share what does social change mean for you and how can we truly create a better world.

Do you sometimes attribute your success or achievements to luck or chance? Do you often feel like you are never quite good enough? These are common feelings attributed to imposter syndrome, or, the experience of doubting or questioning your achievements despite evidence to the contrary. Many MIT students, faculty and staff experience imposter syndrome themselves at various points in their lives and careers, so you are not alone!


At UPOP, students work in teams to confront topics such as impostor syndrome with tailored guidance from staff and industry mentors. Throughout the year, student teams work to gain confidence in their communication, problem solving and teamwork skills while achieving career development milestones.


Join us for this self-reflective and interactive workshop led by UPOP Student Program Administrator, Justin Crim, and a special UPOP community member.


This event is open to all first-years across all majors. Zoom meeting password = UPOP

MIT’s Solar Electric Vehicle Team (SEVT) is faced with a unique challenge: design, manufacture, and construct a solar-powered vehicle from scratch to compete in a long distance endurance race. By long distance, we mean about 2,000 miles. Students from across disciplines come together to create a community of teammates and friends working to solve real-world problems with significant impacts. Apart from engineering, members learn invaluable business and project-management skills by approaching this challenge from a higher level. As a student-run team, this project is our heart and soul, and we are able to learn and grow as engineers, teammates, and people as we face new challenges in the world of solar.

objects.name: Online Registration Forms Due - MANDATORY for First Year Students!

description_html.en-US: MANDATORY for first year students! You must hit 'submit' as the last step for class registration, by 5pm on Thursday, August 27.

Full List of SCUFFY events available here.


Excited to be starting your first year at MIT, or worried about Zoom classes? Either way, all the upperclassmen are here for you! We’re virtualizing the classic MIT first-year experience, so that you can find and join a dorm community that works for you. Find out more at scuffy.mit.edu!


We’re having an extravaganza of 173 events from August 23-30 to showcase all our wild and wacky dorms and cultural houses. On August 27 and 28, you’ll be able to rank the dorms, and get placed in a community by August 30! Note: participation in SCUFFY is optional, but encouraged. The SCUFFY Dorm Placement is not tied to Housing and Residential Services, and will have no bearing on your housing assignments in future semesters.


You can also try to join one of MIT’s 5 Cultural Houses, each with its own cultural connections and set of commitments. Find out more at this page, and if you’re interested make sure you join an info session!


Questions? Email ask-scuffy@mit.edu.

Head over to the #slack-chat-ifc channel in the Orientation 2020 workspace to talk with members of IFC exec about Greek Life at MIT. Can't make this time? No worries! The transcript will live on.

The Interfraternity Council (IFC) consists of 25 all-male fraternities, two co-ed fraternities, and one all-female sorority. Joining an organization within the IFC is your opportunity to become friends with people who share your interests, your values, and your future aspirations. Members hail from all around the world, can be found excelling in all majors at MIT, are involved in countless organizations, hold leadership positions, and consistently achieve impressive GPA's. After graduation they go on to become leaders in their field - whether it be industry or academia - all while preserving the life-long friendships formed in their time here. IFC rush will be held in the spring however, there are a number of ways to explore our constituent organizations during the fall semester. To learn more and receive information about upcoming events, sign up here. By engaging with the IFC community in the fall, you will have a good idea of what IFC organizations you would like to visit and explore further during formal rush process in the spring. Should you have any questions please email IFC President Nico Salinas (ifc-president@mit.edu) or IFC Recruitment Chair Maximilian Porlein (ifc-rushchair@mit.edu).

Head over to the #slack-chat-panhel channel in the Orientation 2020 workspace to talk with members of Panhel exec about Greek Life at MIT. Can't make this time? No worries! The transcript will live on.

MIT Panhellenic is the largest women’s+ community on campus, consisting of over 500 total members across 7 sorority chapters. Committed to embodying a culture of diversity and inclusion, empowerment, and high achievement, the sorority experience at MIT is unlike any other. It provides its members with academic support, life-long friendship, leadership opportunities, alumni connections, and a "home under the dome" through its values of sisterhood, scholarship, service, leadership, integrity, growth, and respect. Our members maintain high GPAs, publish in top academic journals, participate in the arts and athletics, and are actively involved in student groups such as the Undergraduate Association, Rainbow Lounge, Pleasure, and more. Sorority life provides the opportunity for members to establish bonds with some of the most passionate, compassionate, and driven people on campus — bonds that will last a lifetime. Learn more about us (including eligibility, inclusivity, and how to join our community) by checking out our instagram (@mitpanhel) or visiting panhel.mit.edu and clicking the "About" and "Recruitment" pages!

Head over to the #slack-chat-mgc channel in the Orientation 2020 workspace to talk with members of MGC leadership & alumni about Greek Life at MIT. Can't make this time? No worries! The transcript will live on.

MIT’s Multicultural Greek Council (MGC) is a council currently representing four organizations: Alpha Phi Alpha Fraternity, Inc., Alpha Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc., Kappa Alpha Psi Fraternity, Inc., and Delta Sigma Theta Sorority, Inc. These city-wide organizations are members of the National Panhellenic Council (NPHC), a group of nine Black greek-letter organizations that foster a holistic collegiate experience and a life-long membership commitment to service and excellence. MGC is inclusive to the other organizations within the NPHC, the National Association of Latino Fraternal Organizations (NALFO), National APIA Panhellenic Association (NAPA), the National Multicultural Greek Council (NMGC), and other multicultural umbrella and/or national or international multicultural organizations. If you’re interested in MGC, please contact mgc-leadership@mit.edu. Membership in MGC is open to all full-time undergraduates of MIT.

Head over to the #slack-chat-ilg channel in the Orientation 2020 workspace to talk with members of the ILG community at MIT. Can't make this time? No worries! The transcript will live on.

MIT has five Independent Living Groups: ET (Epsilon Theta), Fenway House, pika, Student House, and WILG (Women's Independent Living Group). Each ILG offers a living opportunity that you won't find anywhere else. ILGs are close- knit, inclusive communities with a strong sense of personality, culture, and fun. Most are co-ed, have a communal dining program, and have regular social events. The most important aspects of our communities, however, the culture, social life, and atmosphere vary widely from house to house; each ILG prides itself on its own unique perks and quirks. If you might be interested in the ILGs, either as a place to live or just for free food and fun events, come check us out during our recruitment periods, which vary house to house. You can find more information about the individual houses at lgc.mit.edu, or by emailing lgc-exec@mit.edu.

objects.name: Finding God at MIT - Cru Weekly Gathering

description_html.en-US:
Zoom Link: https://mit.zoom.us/j/98431312183


Will I find friends at MIT who will help me grow closer to God? Yes! Come check out Cru, a diverse group of students who are seeking to follow Jesus at MIT. Grab your favorite snack and beverage, find a comfortable place to sit and come enjoy a time of worship with the Cru band and hear inspiring stories from students who have found out how to thrive in their faith at college. We’ll hear a short message from the Bible and have time in breakout rooms to meet other first years and upperclassmen in Cru. Great giveaways too! Cru is a non-denominational Christian student group on campus. If you can’t make it, please stop by www.mitcru.com to learn more and fill out a connect form.
